PCI.BIO: Oliver Williams, C.S.C. specializes in the areas of business ethics, corporate governance, and Catholic social teaching. Williams is the editor or author of 22 books as well as numerous articles on business ethics in journals. He is the Director of the Notre Dame Center for Ethics and Religious Values in Business in the Mendoza College of Business at the University of Notre Dame. A former Naval Officer, Williams earned his doctorate from Vanderbilt University and his bachelor’s and master’s degrees from Notre Dame. He is a Catholic priest in the Congregation of Holy Cross. He served as Associate Provost of the University of Notre Dame from 1987-94 and is a past chair of the Social Issues Division of the Academy of Management. He was elected as a Professor Extraordinary at Stellenbosch University in South Africa in 2014. In 2006, he was appointed a member of the three-person Board of Directors at the United Nations Global Compact Foundation. The United Nations Global Compact is the world’s largest voluntary corporate citizenship initiative with over 8,000 businesses around the world as members.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: Writer of an Introduction
AWARDHONOR.ORG: Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace
AWARDHONOR.DESC: I was invited to write an Introduction to the Korean translation of VOCATION OF THE BUSINESS LEADER: A REFLECTION. This document was formulated under the direction of Cardinal Peter Turkson, President of the Pontifical Council for Justice and Peace of the Vatican.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: Elected to Professor Extraordinary at the University of Stellenbosch, South Africa
AWARDHONOR.DESC:
"The University created this category of appointments to give recognition to individuals for their proven specialized expertise, and/or their eminence in their profession and field of study, and to involve them in the academic programmes of the Stellenbosch Business School.
The same criteria as for the appointment of Professors to the University's establishment apply when any candidate is assessed for appointment as Professor Extraordinary."

AWARDHONOR.NAME: International Scholar and Visiting Professor
AWARDHONOR.DESC: For the 2012-13 AY, I have served at Kyung Hee University involved with teaching and research.

AWARDHONOR.NAME: As a Board Member of the U.N. Global Compact Foundation, I was invited to its meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in conjunction with the U.N. Conference on Sustainable Development "Rio+20"
The Christopher Chair in Business Ethics at Dominican University
AWARDHONOR.DESC: Selected for the Christopher Chair in Business Ethics at Dominican University. This entailed being present at various activities and working with the faculty on ethical issues at Dominican University for approximately eight days of the 2011-12 academic year.

CONGRANT.TITLE: Projects of the Center for Ethics and Religious Values in Business
CONGRANT.SPONORG: Hershey Food Company and the William Lehr, Jr. Foundation

CONGRANT.ABSTRACT: An annual grant to fund MBA students to work in black townships in South Africa for June and July (1999 to 2003). The project entailed helping small businesses become more efficient. In 2003 eight MBA students participated.
Hershey Food Co. Foundation. Funding for Research Projects of the Center for Ethics and Religious Values in Business. 15,000 granted each year.
Merck, J&J, Bristol Myers Squibb, Pfizer and Novartis contributed for the project on HIV/AIDS and Multinational Responsibility: 2001-2003.

INTELLCONT.CONTYPEOTHER: Editor and contributor to a refereed book
INTELLCONT.ABSTRACT: The book focuses on how business can promote peace. Chapters address the purpose of the corporation; the influence of legal and peace studies;and the experience of NGO officials and business leaders. Ten case studies document the efforts of individual businesses in the cause of promoting peace. Final chapters reflect on the conceptual foundations of this new role of business in society.

INTELLCONT_OTHER.TITLE: Center for Ethics and Religious Values in Business, Director
INTELLCONT_OTHER.DESC:
Under the umbrella of the Center for Ethics and Relilgious Values in Business, conferences are organized and some papers are published in volumes widely used in business schools. In November 2006, the conference Peace Through Commerce was convened with several partners: The United Nations, The Kroc Institute for Peace Studies and the AACSB. A book was published in 2008 by the University of Notre Dame Press.
In March 2011 a conference was held at Notre Dame on THE UN MILLENNIUM DEVELOPMENT GOALS, THE GLOBAL COMPACT AND THE COMMON GOOD. Convened by the Center for Ethics and Religious Values in Business, the United Nations Global Compact, and the United Nations Principles for Responsible Management Education Secretriat, the conference brought together scholars, government officials, and leading businesses advancing the Millennium Development Goals, showcasing some of the major figures in the field. See the conference website for details: http://business.nd.edu/globalcompact/ The best essays will be published in 2014 in a book titled SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT: THE U.N. MILLENNIUM DEVELOPMENT GOALS, THE U.N. GLOBAL COMPACT AND THE COMMON GOOD.
